editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: A TRVE COPPIE OF THE ADMONITIONS SENT BY THE SVBdued Provinces to the States of Hollande: and the Hollanders an≈øwere to the ≈øame.

TOGETHER VVITH THE ARTICLES of Peace concluded betweene the high and mightie Princes, PHILLIP by the grace of God King of Spaine, &c. and HENRY the Fourth by the ≈øame grace, the mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of France, in the yeare 1598.

p.hi: Fir≈øt Tran≈ølated out of French into Dutch, and nowe into Engli≈øh by H. VV.

div.p: EDINBVRGH Printed by Robert Walde-graue according to the Copie Printed in LONDON. 1598.

O Noble and high minded Holland, which act ≈øo exalted and e≈øteemed, becau≈øe Fortune ≈ømiles on thee: how long wilt thou liue in this thy wanton fooli≈øhnes, & begine your≈øelfe to force & ≈øtrength? ha≈øt thou not yet ynough followed the trace of di≈øquietnes? ha≈øt thou quite forgot the bonde of a ‚Ä¢ mitie? is it vpon nothing but blood, murther, and fire that thou ≈øtudie≈øt? hath Mars wholly po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed thy hearte? wilt thou haue all according to thy owne minde? Doe≈øt thou thinke that this will all, way run before the wind with th√©e? Do but thinke from whome thou art ≈øeuered? & wherfore hate≈øt thou them that loued th√©e? Thou art our fle≈øh, our blood (in times pa≈ø≈øed in a good mind) but now cruelly bent again≈øt vs. I cannot imagine wherevpon thy foundation is grounded: twenty fiue yeares thus in ≈øtrife to continue, will there bee no ende? doth peace goe again≈øt thy ≈øtomacke? Do≈øt thou not ≈ø√©eke re≈øt and tranquility in thy time? Let the common mi≈øery mooue th√©e.

epigraph.q: No Chri≈øtian is he who in harme taketh delight.

div.p: 2 Wilt thou perpetually crie and braule, and like ≈øauage bea≈øts remaine wild and furious? be the≈øe thy reformed manners to ≈øtirre vp mutinies and rebellion? what wilt thou? what ≈øeeke≈øt thou? what is thy griefe? wherefore ha≈øt thou taken armes? for thy priuiledges this was the fir≈øt play: but truely that was not it: you ≈øought ≈øomething els, as now we may plainely ≈øee: for the experiences lighteneth thy darknes: thou ha≈øt reiected all dutie: & ≈øeeke≈øt (again≈øt God) a liberty to thy own minde. Open thy eyes, marke if the ≈øcriptures teach ≈øuch rules to ≈øubiectes: What hath S. Paule laid before the Chri≈øtians vnder the idolatrous potentates, that they ought to be obedient vnto their ≈øuperiors according to Gods lawes. This le≈ø≈øon had al≈øo bene good in thy behalfe.

epigraph.q: For where pride is, Gods ≈øpirit cannot abide.

div.p:
3 It ≈øeemed that you would bani≈øh tyranny, and with free hearts defend your patrimony: but you ≈øought to ≈øet a≈øide and ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe your ≈øuperiors, and to liue according to your owne fancy. The ≈øhewe was faire, but it had another meaning then ≈øome thought: but by your workes is apparantly perceaued that yet at this day your heart is again≈øt ≈øubiection, you thinke to ≈øtrengthen your ≈øelues with your owne force, and de≈øpi≈øe the Prince whome God and nature hath giuen thee: He calleth, he watcheth, but thou wilt not heare him: He entreates, he admoni≈øheth you, and you do not re≈øpect it: Hee will ioyne him≈øelfe to you, and you refu≈øe it: his goodnes augmenteth your rebellion: he de≈øireth no reuenge, nor cruelty: he will receaue you with grace:
he w ‚Ä¢ ede thee as ‚Ä¢
„Äà‚óä„Äâ of his body, although thou ha≈øt ≈øomewhat e≈øtranged thy ≈øelfe; returne, returne, and refu≈øe not your owne good.

epigraph.q: He de≈øpi≈øeth God who takes that which belongeth to his Prince.

div.p: 4 Do not with ≈øcorne reiect his proffers, but prepare your troubled and ≈øcattred nunds to peace: for though fortune be now on your ≈øide, yet (according to her wonted vn≈øteadfa≈øtnes) the ca≈øe might change, and then your happines and good luck were ≈øoone de≈øtroid: euen as ≈ønow and ‚Ä¢ ce melteth before the ≈øunne, euen ≈øo melteth pro≈øperity when God will ≈øhew his anger: this is manife≈øt, and dayly ≈øeene in diuers per≈øons in this exchaunging mortall life, yea in many kingdomes and countries, which are ≈øeene to fall through their owne default: It is folly to tru≈øt on moueable things, if to day you are happy, to morrow your ≈øtate may alter: and he that tru≈øteth vpon him≈øelfe is often deceaued, before he doth imagine that the wind will blow again≈øt him. O Hollande bee not too proud, although thou art in a moment cap≈øed vp to the toppe of fortunes wheele, for the foundation is naught, how ≈øure ≈øoeuer you thinke it.

epigraph.q: Nothing can dure which hath no good ground.

div.p: 5 Thou art mercifully admoni≈øhed, but with crueltie thou ≈øtoppe≈øt thy eares, and your conceaued furie remaines ≈øo ob≈øtinat that thou wilt not li≈øten to any rea≈øon. Is there nothing that can abate your high minde, nor quench your bloody thir≈øt? the Omnipotent God doth perceaue your ob≈øtinacies and how wilfully you hate peace: No doubt he will vi≈øite thee: his hand doth threat th√©e, as not long ≈øince he hath miraculou≈øly ≈øhewen vnto th√©e, by the greate Whale which was ≈øeene at Scheueling vpon the ≈øtrand, who before your eyes like a thunder did bur≈øt with great rumor & blood≈øhed. Marke and ruminate vpon this, as an e≈øpeciall token, and thinke that this dooth ≈øignifie ≈øome wondrous thing. Let each one that heares this, take warning thereby. And if thou can≈øt ta≈øte truth take warning hereout. Open thy eyes and vnlock thy ≈øtony hearts.

epigraph.q: God alwaies doth warne before he doth puni≈øh.

div.p:
6 Thou art threatned, thats a thing manife≈øtly knowne: for each one can iudge what ≈øuch mon≈øters betoken. Gods mightie and heauy hande is ouer your heads to plague you: with griefe and mi≈øerie he will feade th√©e, yea with aduer≈øity, ruine and pouerty. Thy ioy he will conuert to ≈øorrow, thy laughing to laments, thy riches to nothing, as is ≈øeene: he altereth kingdomes: & that which ≈øtandes high he doeth aba≈øe. This will befall thee vnle≈ø≈øe thou wilt
acknowledge thy ≈øoueraigne as good ≈øubiects. Sheath thy murthering blate, let peace ≈øhine in thy heart before your de≈øtinies fall. Thy neighbours of whome you hope to reape comfort, and vpon who≈øe alliance you ≈øo peremptorily ≈øtande will for≈øake thee, for euery one looketh to him≈øelfe when they are in n√©ede. Of this a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelues, for it is no fable.

epigraph.q: It is commonly ≈øaid, Daunger parteth friend≈øhip.

div.p: 7 Your bad pretences do war again≈øt God: ye are as in ≈øpite of nature it ≈øelfe: although other princes doe their profite with th√©e, yet (notwith≈øtanding) they hate the≈øe your trickes, thinking their ≈øubiects might al≈øo rebell: & reiect their magi≈øtrates: for ≈øoone are founde many colours to reuolt, when once the minde is that way bent, your regiment is ≈øcandalous to all nations that know it, becau≈øe you de≈øpi≈øe ≈øuperiority: for they that reiect their Princes (≈øaith S. Paule) with≈øtande Gods ordinance: you are like vnto the mon≈øter which to the amazement of each one came beatles vpon the ≈øhore of Scheueling, and there (to your learning) remained drie vpon the lande: wherefore learne obedience before the puni≈øhment come: for this ≈øame looking gla≈ø≈øe was not planted in vaine.

epigraph.q: Where grace is, there is alwaies time to repent.

div.p: 8 Yet for all this I imagine you will mocke at this admoni≈øhment, and (as you are wont) ≈øay it is nothing but the prating of Friers, or babling of Nuns: No medicines wil ≈øerue to your ≈øore, for alwaies the malicious mocks with Gods ≈øecrets: True it is, we are neither prophets nor children of prophets: we are far remoued from the knowledge of the diuine hidden ≈øecretes: yet our admoni≈øhment is not without foundation: beleeue if it ≈øo plea≈øe you, for of pure zeale we open vnto you your e≈øtate: a wonderful change is ordained vnto you: choo≈øe the be≈øt while you haue time, you are warned by the highe≈øt Regent. Giue place to rea≈øon, you are expected with grace. O Noble Holland quench your turbation. Ioyne with your bretheren: follow the coun≈øaile of friends and bel√©eue no ≈øtrife makers which will ruine you.

epigraph.q: Vnwi≈øe is he that followes a blind mans trace.

div.p: Is ≈ø√©ene and allowed to be printed.

div.head: The An≈øwere of the Hollanders to the ≈øeduced Prouinces vpon the former Admonition.

div.p: DIuinely and manly Noble Holland is exalted, for God doth of his mercy accept the ≈øame as his childe: be≈øides the defence of our paternall fr√©edome, is the roote from whence nobility ≈øpringes: The≈øe vrge vs Hollanders, and not the blind idolatrous Godde≈ø≈øe, whome wee refer to them that doe ≈øerue her. Prouidentia is our leader, for we finde that ≈øhe doth exalt vs aboue all e≈øtates. Such as ≈øooth vp their enemies, and hate their defenders. Iudge if they bee not to be e≈øteemed as wanton fooles: Thie is our meaning to endeauour to with≈øt and you andour enemies with force and ≈øtrength: And we will, to the ende, as long as neede ≈øhall require defend our common libertie doth daye and night, while≈øt God giues vs ≈øtrength to abide it to fight for our ≈øelues and our neighbours who feede their deadly foe in their bo≈øome, which is a dangerous and pittifull thing.

epigraph.q: For no Chri≈øtian is he that doth bad, and to ≈øtrengthen others therin.

div.head: More vpon the fir≈øt.
div.p: YOu blinde Netherlanders reproch vs that wee haue quite forgot the band of amitie: neyther hath blood, murther, nor fire po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed our harts, neyther do we acknowledge Mars otherwi≈øe then for a blinde idoll, but onely the God of boa≈øt who hath imprinted in our hearts a ≈øtedfa≈øt thought of reconcilement, and peace, as well appeares by diuers our mintes, who outwardely ≈øhew our inwarde minde: we do our be≈øte to reioyne you, that are wrongfully ≈øeuered from vs, to the ende that the Spanyard do not hurt thee: for needefull defence of our libertie and goods is the rule of our pretences, and the bulwarke of our warre as long as Gods grace doth helpe vs, if we did otherwi≈øe we ≈øhould ≈øhame the Netherland blood. And Chri≈øt hath warned vs to be again≈øt Lyons and Foxes rauenous and crafte.

epigraph.q: Simple as Doues, and ≈øuttle as Snakes.

div.p:
YOu cannot compare vs to Beares or Wolues, who are full of crueltie ≈øuttle Foxes nor Dragons who long for bloud, for wee are tame as Lambes, guarded by Dogs, who≈øe teeth defende vs from the wild bea≈øtes, (becau≈øe wee are reformed) ≈øuch is to vs not forbidden, we v≈øe it to our defence. Our will, our ≈ø√©eking is that we do inuite, ≈øeeke and procure, through the commandement of Chri≈øt your ≈øafetie with ours both of bodie and ≈øoule: Our griefe is that you feele not your lo≈ø≈øe nor the dead: the cau≈øe of our taking armes is to defende our lawfull priuiledges, together with the libertie
of mind, and this is the only way to get the ≈øame, as in the≈øe our countries is apparantly to be ≈øeene, that this is the only marke we ≈øhout at, which we al≈øo will with deedes ≈øhew vnto you, if you will ioyne with vs, and with≈øtande the Spani≈øh packe.

epigraph.q: Who≈øe pride is vnto God and man an horror.

div.head: More vpon the ≈øecond.
div.p: THe obedience which wee ≈øhew vnto our ≈øuperiours is willinglie without force, yea with iu≈øt de≈øire, as our contraries ≈øee and prai≈øe, although it doe ≈øpite them, and ≈øhewes that we ≈øeeke nothing but to obay according to the teaching of the wi≈øe: it appeares by that which we haue done, and ≈øuffered ≈øo long, for to remaine vnder the kings regiment as our Lorde but not as a tyrant: we could do no le≈ø≈øe: we ≈øeeke but the libertie, which no Chri≈øtian Prince ought to refu≈øe to obedient Chri≈øtians, without the which we could not continue, nor be e≈øteemed good Chri≈øtians. For according to the ≈øcriptures (which we reade more then you do) for they are forbidden your ≈øights as a thing nothing touching your vocation: we finde that our faults are agr√©eing together, therefore he that is not content to doe mi≈øchiefe him≈øelfe, but exhorteth his neighbour al≈øo, their ambition verily ≈øheweth that God hath wholly pulled his grace from him.

epigraph.q: For God to the proud doth euer giue a fall.

div.p: IN effect, we ≈øeeke to expell tyrannie, and with a ioyfull hart defend our natiue ≈øoyle from your incur≈øions: and (through Gods helpe haue pre≈øerued ≈øome part thereof to your good) hope to per≈øeuer further therein: wee neuer yet de≈øired to liue headle≈ø≈øe, or without Magi≈øtrates, for wee account them vnwi≈øe which de≈øire it. But it is wi≈øedome to take a care thereof, and to haue Magi≈øtrates of our owne nation. As God hath alwaies exhorted his people. We ≈øtande not vpon our owne ≈øtrength, but with heart and mind put our whole tru≈øt and defence in Gods handes. Our Prince we do not ≈øcorne, but feare the tyrant, who (according to Gods lawes) hath lo≈øt his right. His entreaties makes vs ≈øigh, perceiuing nothing in him, but the fruites of the ≈øick Lyon, to whom the Foxe for all his flatterie would giue no reliefe, for his deeds to others ≈øhew the intent of his heart.

epigraph.q: He that v≈øeth his right doth no body wrong.

div.head: More vpon the third.
div.p:
YOur Prince calles and watches, as a Wolfe wounted lyeth a bedde, reque≈øting the Lambe to giue him ≈øome drinke, ≈øaying that afterwards he
would prouide meate him≈øelfe. To whome the ≈øilly Lambe ‚Ä¢ reth „Äà‚óä„Äâ doing: yea marrie you would make me your ‚Ä¢ de: I per ‚Ä¢ your drift So the remembrance of his Lyon-like and Wolfe-like crueltie, doth make vs to e≈øteeme his calling, and entreating of no worthe: you boa≈øt much of his goodne≈ø≈øe: you marke not the place nor per≈øon to whom you ≈øpeake, where ≈øcarce there is a ≈øteppe but his crueltie hath bene ≈øhowen, to what ende will you excu≈øe him? he hath manife≈øtly ≈øhewed the ≈øame lately at Bru≈ø≈øels vpon the body of a ≈øilly mayden. Why? you ≈øpeake it to Hollanders, who yet ≈ømell the fire of their late de≈øtruction of goods and blood, yea who≈øe woundes are yet bleeding, his mercie which hath ≈øhewed vs his ≈øword, fire, and halter, neuer yet did he reach vs a fatherly hand, and yet he beares a very ≈ømooth face: but as the old Prouerbe ≈øayeth, which teacheth vs.

epigraph.q: He hath or will deceiue him where he can.

div.head: More vpon the third.
div.p: WE can ≈øoone iudge what mercie wee ≈øhould finde at the handes of him, who e≈øteemeth his highnes wronged in the highe≈øt degree for the≈øe foure poynts again≈øt his maie≈øtie. As Armes again≈øt him, new religion, to be ≈øworne again≈øt him: traffiking with other Potentates. Do you call this but ≈øome what e≈øtranged? what mercie can we expect of him who e≈øteemeth the re≈øignement of a ≈ømall reque≈øt of ≈øtate a great di≈øgrace to his highne≈ø≈øe. He whome with vnmercifull tyrannie hath not v≈øed (the vnknowne. We≈øt Indian Amercians, together with the wronged countries of Granada and Arragon) as ≈øubiects, but more like a rauening Wolfe, and all becau≈øe they had but de≈øired their wonted libertie, their teares could not mooue his ≈øtony & wretched heart, but other hardened the ≈øame: what can a≈ø≈øure vs not to be v≈øed in like ≈øort. Wherfore we tru≈øt in our God, h ‚Ä¢ (without doubt will ≈øtrengthen vs, vpon him as vpon a firme rock is our warre grounded.

epigraph.q: Again≈øt God, neyther money, coun≈øell, nor friends can p. euaile.

div.p:
NEuer Letter or me≈ø≈øenger hath bene ≈øent to vs, but they haue ben read, and euery word vnder≈øtood and an≈øwered: in≈øomuch that they might well perceiue that wee ≈øought nothing better then a good peace. Hartius with his can witnes the ≈øame your idolatrous fortune (where withall in your admoni≈øhment you there twice threatned vs) we e≈øteeme her not a figge. Let Heathens and their like adore her, we acknowledge the ≈øtedfa≈øt prouidence of God, who altereth the kingdomes. Them that haue taken their dwelling places in the heanens, and made their ne≈øtes in the clowdes. To his will and not to fortune do we giue the honour, where vnder onelie
do we ≈øub ‚Ä¢ our ≈øelues. This is ≈ø√©ene by the Spani≈øh king your Lord, w ‚Ä¢ if he had taken this for a warning ≈øhould neuer haue come to this his diuli≈øh pride, whereby he hath greately begi ‚Ä¢ to de≈øcend.

epigraph.q: God ≈øtrikes downe the proud, and ray≈øeth the humble.

div.head: More vpon the fourth.
div.p: THe chiefe≈øt things which do ruine a kingdome are, idolatrie, which of God is hated: tyranny to their ≈øubiects, & wrong to their neighbours: for the≈øe offences doth God puni≈øh kingdomes: but Holland ≈øhall yet reioyce, and as a lambe ≈øtanding vpon Gods towre, laughes at the Wolfes threates, being a≈ø≈øured that nothing can hurt him. What token, what fruite of marcie, whereof you boa≈øt can≈øt thou ≈øhew vs of his mercifull d√©edes, & yet lately you would haue murthered our Prince: the≈øe be your di≈ø≈øembling admoni≈øhments: away away with them. The vnquenchable blood thir≈øt of tho≈øe diuili≈øh gra≈øhoppers your Ie≈øuites, ye cuffians who gouerne your King, do teach vs not to tru≈øt your di≈ø≈øembling words.

epigraph.q: The kingdome grounded vpon murther cannot ≈øtand.

div.p: WE haue bin often cruelly awakened when we did not ≈øleepe, that tho≈øe which were awakened neuer ro≈øe againe, in≈øomuch that they that heard the knocks were a≈øtoni≈øhed, yet neuer had we any warning thereof by tho≈øe that could haue ≈øent it vs. But of you who acknowledge to haue no ≈øtrength, becau≈øe you are bent vnder the Spani≈øh yoke, and the Gouernour who≈øe force is enclo≈øed by the Spani≈øh Coun≈øaile, and ≈øhewe their commi≈ø≈øions to plea≈øure their may≈øters: therfore it is good to admoni≈øh where one may haue thankes for it: but our eare is ≈øo ≈øurely ≈øtopt that we can hardly heare, for wee haue Batauam aurem, an eare which is thicke, which will not be tempted, but as the Snake goeth ≈øubtilly, ≈øtopping her eares to the deceiuers note, ≈øo will we not harken to your Syren-like words.

epigraph.q: The birders whi≈øtle is ≈øweete, when the birds he will intrapt.

div.head: More vpon the fift.
div.p:
GOd (for a while) hath fatherly cha≈øti≈øed vs, both to puni≈øh vs & to rueine vs, and not alone perceauing our ≈øins, but al≈øo our mi≈øeries, which alwaies haue cryed vengance vnto heauen vpon the Spaniards heads, who (as it ≈øeemeth of his mercy) hath heard our clamors. If God did prophe≈øie any thing by the whale which appeared vpon our ≈øhore: what that may betoken we know not, for it may well be ≈øuch things may come to pa≈ø≈øe without any ≈øignification, much le≈ø≈øe know wee what God doth hereby meane: yet your expo≈øition as full ≈øelfe wi≈øe ≈øecr√©etes wee e≈øteeme too fooli≈øh and ra≈øh: but we doe not wonder, for the text of the matter is either fal≈øly reported
vnto you, or by you fal≈øly contriued, for the fi≈øh was not headle≈ø≈øe, as in your ≈øeuenth ver≈øe you ≈øay, but contraryly he had more head then was proportionable to his bodie, the ≈øame being mea≈øured: but what may this ≈øignifie.

epigraph.q: For Gods tokens commonly threaten Gods enemies.

div.head: More vpon the fifth.
div.p: Nowe this is our expo≈øition which you cannot comprehende. This Whale is the greate Spani≈øh Leuiathan, for he and the fi≈øh in nature are like, for as that fi≈øh of other fi≈øhes is the deuourer, ≈øo he al≈øo of other kingdomes is the deuourer and de≈øtroyer. The fi≈øhes head was aboue his proportion, and ≈øo is the Spaniarde, vn≈øatiably gr√©edie to ouer-gape all, though it co≈øt him his life. It is manife≈øt in England, France, and the Netherlandes: By the Whales bur≈øting is meant that the Spaniard directing his force towardes England, for to ≈øubdue that with his neighbors, is there al≈øo runne aground, bur≈øt and ≈øpoyled, to the ioy of all, and e≈øpecially of vs, who hope that God will cau≈øe him to runne him≈øelfe dead, if he will not cea≈øe to per≈øecute the innocent.

epigraph.q: He that per≈øecutes another doth often fall him≈øelfe in trouble.

div.p: IF euer there was any people threatned and cro≈ø≈øed by their enemies it is we, and by you watched, wherefore we reiect your ≈øugred wordes, which you began with vs euen again≈øt God, as by your vnadui≈øe expo≈øition of the fi≈øh which was driuen vpon our ≈øhore, without hurt or daunger to anie: yea which is more, was profite for the country, wherefore we e≈øteeme that Gods tokens and threats are more ≈øtronger then many Wolues and Beares, who both hurt men and cattell, the ≈øwarming multitudes of dying bea≈øtes, who vexe & de≈øtroy the fruits of trees & growth of the earth: they are mo≈øt Gods plagues. So that this fi≈øh pa≈ø≈øeth without prophe≈øying any puni≈øhmeÃÑt to vs.

epigraph.q: But Gods wrath ouer them that ≈øeeke to hurt vs.

div.head: More vpon the ≈øixt.
div.p:
WE acknowledge and confe≈ø≈øe that wee haue de≈øerued Gods iu≈øt puni≈øhment, but we hope that his wrath will per≈øecute the Spaniardes vntill ≈øuch time as they leaue per≈øecuting the iu≈øt. The example wee ≈øhall ≈ø√©e vpon th√©e O King, who wert ray≈øed to the top of the cloudes ≈øhalt fall downe without ≈øtay vntill thou acknowledge God in his force. We haue long ynough to the lo≈ø≈øe of our bloud helde him for our Prince, till at length we haue reiected him and for≈øworne his allyance, which pure n√©ede hath cau≈øed, the verdite whereof we remit vnto our Lord God. Vpon England & France we will not boa≈øt, the humaine arme is weake & to no effect:
but God is our, fortre≈ø≈øe and that we conioyne with our neighbours, wh ‚Ä¢ are coparteners with vs in like woes, is no ≈øhame, and their reuolt with your threats doth not make vs ≈øhrinke.

epigraph.q: The feare of common ruine bindes friend≈øhip fa≈øter.

div.p: IDolatry doth warre again≈øt Gods learning, and that you reproch vs. God and nature doth ordaine Princes for their ≈øubiects defence and profite, when now the Prince through enuie and tyrannie doth abu≈øe his power, and his va≈ø≈øalles, then doeth God take away from him the vertue and right which he had giuen him by nature, yet not all princes, but tho≈øe that ≈øuppre≈ø≈øe their people with iniu≈øtice. England and France are out of thy reproch, for their kinde gouernement commendes our d√©eds. The ≈øcandall which you ≈øpake of haue we not giuen: but if any hypocrite doth ≈øcandalize him≈øelfe, it is his owne folly, to trouble him≈øelfe with that which is not worth a myte. You al≈øo doe call vs rebelles: whereof we are comforted long ≈øince, for our patience doth chaunge the minds of diuers, who offer vs of loue a furthering hand.

epigraph.q: If ≈øo be we do not herden our ≈øelues to beginne mi≈øchiefe

div.head: More vpon the ≈øeuenth.
div.p: THo≈øe that according to their countrie lawes do defend their countries right, are lawfull Magi≈øtrates, which wee not refu≈øe, nor yet reiects them, as you ≈øpitefully reproch vs. We re≈øi≈øt the tyrant, according to the iudgement of any, yet doe we not tran≈øgre≈ø≈øe the ordinances of God: neyther do we reiect the admonition of S. Paule. But the word of God teacheth that lawfull magi≈øtrates are placed by him to keepe their people in peace and quietne≈ø≈øe and to cha≈øti ‚Ä¢ the wicked: When now they beginne with tyrannous ≈øugge≈øtions to opp ‚Ä¢ ≈øe their ≈øubiects, with iu≈øt cau≈øe may they bee depo≈øed, as breakers of the≈øe contractes, and their ≈øubiectes are not baunde to ≈øhew them any more obedience. Becau≈øe nowe this Spaniarde is like vnto the mon≈øter in euerie degr√©e: we ‚Ä¢ e flie his bl ‚Ä¢ thir≈øtie tirranny.

epigraph.q: Vnwi≈øe is he to ≈øeeke mercie where none is to be found.

div.p:
THe vnadui≈øed di≈øcour≈øe, fiered out of the mouth of a madde man without ground or meaning is mocked and ≈øcoffed at euery where, as fooli≈øh wordes, but they that be any way allyed vnto him by kinred or friend≈øhip, and that do loue him, are grieuou≈øly ≈øorry, for thereby they know the vncurable madne≈ø≈øe where withall he is po≈ø≈øe≈øt. Euen thus is it with vs towardes you, who mocks others, giuing vs no other hope to cure your madne≈ø≈øe:
you are wholly vnapt to take good coun≈øaile: we loue trueth, but your fayned di≈øcour≈øe interlarded with diuer≈øitie of fine phrai≈øed lyes, doth make vs a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues, that either you are po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed with madne≈ø≈øe, or with Spaniards, to yours and our ruine, and de≈øtruction of your patrimonie.

epigraph.q: He that per≈øueth ruine, ≈øhall ≈øoone ouertake it.

div.head: More vpon the eight.
div.p: YOur accu≈øation is better: your admoni≈øhment to peace and obedience is without grounde. That you do it of pure zeale we bel√©eue the ≈øame al≈øo: But your zeale is fooli≈øh and blinde: you ≈øay that a wonderfull chaunge is ordained for vs, this you grounde vpon your peace with the French Nation: What more hurtful mutation can befal then to be in a league with Wolues? But if you are no Prophets, whithertended then your oration, for the Lambe for although he had pleadges dares not commit him≈øelfe to the Wolues mercy, he rather would deuour both Lambe and pledges, then hee would let the Lambe liue. We know the decr√©e giuen in the Popes Councell: That one ought not to keepe faith vnto heretickes. We haue ≈ø√©ene it in manie to whome it hath co≈øt their liues. But indeede you haue your wi≈øh, ioyning your d√©des with ours, not li≈øting to ≈øtrife-makers: for he is vnwi≈øe that reputes his friends his enemies.

q.p: And a more foole is hee, who his foes for friends takes to be.

div.p: Printed at Am≈øterdam for Laurence Iacobs Stationer, vpon the water in the bible.

div.head: Articles and conditions of the peace and perpetuall lyance concluded betweene the high and Mightie Princes PHILLIP by the grace of God, Catholike King of Spaine &c. And HENRY the Fourth of that name by the ≈øame grace mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of France Anno 1598.
Whereunto are annexed the Articles of the Peace concluded in the Ca≈øtle of Cambre≈øii, Anno 1559. betweene the Catholike King of Spaine, & the late Henry the ≈øecond mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of France.
div.byline: Fir≈øt tran ‚Ä¢ lated out of French into Dutch, and now into our vulgar tongue by H. W. In the name of God the Creator.
div.p:
BE it knowen vnto all men pre≈øent, and to come, that as the Realme of France & the Netherl ‚Ä¢ ndi≈øh Prouinces, haue endured great lo≈ø≈øe & damage, by rea≈øon of the ciuill and forraigne warres, who haue continued the≈øe many yeares, which the kingdomes of England and Spaine, and
the countries of Sauoy haue well knowne and felt, while in the meane time the common enemie to Chri≈øtendome and the Chri≈øtian name, marking his welfare o ‚Ä¢ our ruine, procuring to ≈øurmount vs through our ≈øtrife, hath gotten a perilous proc√©eding, in his vnlawfull ≈øugge≈øtion of the Chri≈øtian Prouinces, the which being con≈øiddered by our Holie Father Clemene the eight of that name, and de≈øiring with all diligence to Preuent the ≈øame, and to cut a≈øunder the roote of this mi≈øchiefe, and hath through his Me≈ø≈øenger dwelling at „Äà‚óä„Äâ a drill, and other doone, and pronounced diuers demon≈øtrations, and exhortations vnto the high and mighty Prince Phillip the ≈øecond, by the grace of God Catholike king of Ca≈øtile, Aragon, Leno, and both citties of Ieru≈øalem, of Portingall and Granada &c. to the end to bring him vnto an amiable peace and accorde, with the mo≈øt high & mightie Prince. Henry the Fourth by the ≈øame grace mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King of France and Nauare, vnto whom h ‚Ä¢ s holines had ≈øent the illu≈øtrous and reuerend Cardinall of Florence Alexander de Medicis Legatte to him and to the Apo≈øtolique Seate, to pronounce like exhortations vnto the ≈øaide mo≈øte Chri≈øtian kinge, and according as our ≈øaide Holy Father hath b√©ene aduerti≈øed that the ≈øaide Catholike kinge had giuen full power and in≈øtruction to conclude this peace vnto the high & mightie prince Albertus Cardinall, Arch Duke of Au≈øtria. his nephew, and al≈øo for the greate good tru≈øte which be had in him, and affection which he hath alwaies had to the ≈øaid peace, had ≈øent vnto him the reuerent Father I. Bonauenture Cala
‚Ä¢ agirono. Generall of the order of S. Frances, to the ende he might by him vnder≈øtand his meaning in this matter, and al≈øo to giue him further knowledge of the meaning of the ≈øaide Catholike king touching this peace, hauing pre≈øented all what is afore≈øaid vnto the ≈øaid mo≈øt chri≈øtian king according to the order which he had receaued of his holines, the ≈øaid kings incited through a godly zeale, pitty and griefe which they conceaued and felt in their hearts, of the long heauie and burthen≈øome mi≈øerie, which through continuance of the ≈øaid wars their kingdomes, countries and ≈øubiects haue and yet endure: in
‚Ä¢ ending not to let ≈ølip an occa≈øion which con≈øi≈øteth in the power of God fea
‚Ä¢ ing Princes, and that loue their ≈øubiects, to bring and perpetually place an a≈ø≈øured peace and tranquility in this land, and e≈øpecially in the prouinces ouer ‚Ä¢ he which it hath plea≈øed God to con≈øtitute them as their k√©epers and defenders, and d√©epely con≈øidering (as their duty is) the graue and wi≈øe con≈øidera
‚Ä¢ ions and exhortations of our ≈øaid holy father, and being therevpon agr√©ede haue reque≈øted their friendes, and allies, with them to vnder≈øtand and re≈øolue a good peace and vnion, to the re≈øt and quietnes of all the Chri≈øtian prouinces, and to the reuiuing and tranquility of all the ≈øubiectes, and to beginne the ≈øaide treatie haue b ‚Ä¢ appointed, to wit by the ≈øaide Cardinall arch Duke,
for and in the name of the ≈øame catholike king, and by vertue ‚Ä¢ d expre≈ø ‚Ä¢ power which he hath of his maie≈øtie. The Lord Iohn Richardo ‚Ä¢
knight & head pre≈øident of the priuy coun≈øale of e≈øtate, the Lord Iohn Bapti≈øt de Taxis knight commander in the Saintes of the war like order of S. Iacob, & of the ≈øaide coun≈øaile of e≈øtate, and coun≈øaile of the war: and the Lord Lewis Vereylen knight audiencier. and chiefe Secretary, and Tre≈øurer of the Briefs and of the fore≈øaid coun≈øaile of e≈øtate, and of the ≈øide of the mo≈øt chri≈øtian king, the Lord Pomponius de Bellieure knight, Lord of Grigon, Coun≈øaylor of his coun≈øaile of e≈øtate, and the Lord Nicholas Bru≈ølart, knight, Lord of Sildeny al≈øo Coun≈øaylor of the ≈øaid king in his coun≈øaile of e≈øtate and Pre≈øident in the court of Parliament of Paris all furni≈øhed with ≈øufficient power, the which at the end herof ≈øhalbe inferred, which lords deputies by vertue of their power in profe of the ≈øaid Cardinall who hath long time laboured to the furthering of this pre≈øent peace, haue concluded & agreed vpon the≈øe articles following.

1 Inprimis it is concluded and agreed, that the treatie of peace ≈øhall continue re≈øolued and concluded, betw√©ene the Lords, Kings, Phillip the 2. and Henry the 4. confirming in approbation of the articles comprehended in the treatie of Peace made vpon the ca≈øtell of Cambre≈øis in the yeare 1559. betweene the ≈øaid Catholike K. Phillip the 2. and of high and lautable memory Henry King of France, all which ≈øaid treatie the ≈øaid deputes haue againe newlie confirmed and ratified in all poyntes, in ≈øuch order as if it were her inferred, from word to word without renewing any thing in the ≈øame nor in any other before, which all ≈øhall continue whole and entire, except that which ≈øhalbe annulled in this pre≈øent treaties.

2 And according to the ≈øame, that from the date of the≈øe pre≈øents betw√©ene the ≈øaid Lords, Kings, their children pre≈øent and to come, their heires and ≈øucce≈ø≈øors, their kingdomes, countries, and ≈øubiectes, ≈øhall be a good, ≈øure, ≈øtable, and inuiolable peace, confederation, eternall alliance and friend≈øhip, ≈øhall al≈øo loue one an other like brethren, ≈ø√©eking and procuring with all duty the others welfare, honor and reputation, and ≈øhall faithfully ≈øhun (for ≈øo much as ≈øhall be po≈ø≈øible) the one the others hurt, not entertayning nor fauoring any per≈øons what≈øoeuer, which ≈øhould be any waies ≈øubiect to the hurte or damage, of the one or the other, and ≈øhall from this day forwarde cea≈øe all enmity, forgetting from this day all thinges, that may haue b√©ene euill done how and what≈øoeuer they be, they ≈øhall put in obliuion and annuled without at any time after the ≈øame ≈øhal be any wais ray≈øed, or mentioned, reiecting by this pre≈øent treatie, al practi≈øes, or inteligences which in any ≈øorte ≈øhould be to the detriment, the one of the other: al≈øo promi≈øing not to do, per≈øue nor procure through any to be done any thing that might tend to the hurt the one to the other, not al≈øo ≈øuffer that their ≈øubiects ≈øhal either
‚Ä¢ ectly or indirectly do the ≈øame, and if ≈øo be any of th ‚Ä¢ of what qualitie or condition ≈øoouer, ≈øhould from the date hereof chance to doe any thing to the contrarie, eyther by ≈øea or land, or otherwi≈øe a≈ø≈øi≈øt or helpe in matters that might be any waie hurtefull vnto the ≈øaide Lordes, Kings, the other ≈øhall be bounde to oppo≈øe him ≈øelfe there again≈øt and hinder the ≈øame, and ≈øeuerely to puni≈øh them as breakers of this peace, & di≈øturbers of the common quietnes.

3 And through vertue of this peace and amitie, the ≈øubiects of both ≈øides what≈øoeuer they are, ≈øo far forth they k√©epe the lawes and cu≈øtomes of the countrie ≈øhalbe ≈øuffered, to go, come, remaine dwell, conuer≈øe and returne in the one and others countrie, v≈øing the trade of merchandi≈øe, or as be≈øt ≈øhall ‚Ä¢ ike them, as well by ≈øea as by land, and vpon the fre≈øh waters frequent and trade together, and the ≈øaid ≈øubiectes ≈øhall be defended in paying rea≈øonably the rightes and duties in al places v≈øed, and others which by their maie≈øties, or their ≈øucce≈ø≈øors ≈øhall be impo≈øed.

4 And all letters of repriualles which might haue bene giuen for what cau≈øe ≈øoeuer ≈øhalbe ≈øu≈øpended, and from this day forwarde there ≈øhalbe none more giuen, by any of the ≈øaid Princes to the preiudice of the others ≈øubiects, except onely again≈øt the chiefe offendours, their goods and of their complices and that yet in ca≈øe of manife≈øt denegation of iu≈øtice, of which & of the letters of reformation & requi≈øition of tho≈øe which ≈øhal pur≈øue the ≈øaid letters repriuals ≈øhalbe bound to make appeare in maner & forme as iniu≈øtice is required.

5 The citties, ≈øubiects cittizens and inhabitantes of the counties of Flanders and Artoiis, & other Prouinces of Netherland, together with the kingdome of Spaine ≈øhall enioy the Priuiledges, and freedomes which haue b√©ene granted betweene the kinges of Frances predice≈ø≈øors of the ≈øaid mo≈øt Chri≈øtian King: and al≈øo the citties ≈øubiects, and cittizens and inhabitantes of the kingdome of France ≈øhall likewi≈øe enioy the liberties and freedomes which they haue in the ≈øaid low countries and kingdomes of Spaine, and as euerie one of them hath heretofore enioyed them, & as they doe enioy them by vertue of the treatie of the yeare 1559. and other precedents.

6 Al≈øo it is couenanted and agr√©ede, that if in ca≈øe the ≈øaide King Catholike do geue or tran≈øfer by te≈øtament, or what title ≈øoeuer it be vnto the worthy Princes the Lady I≈øabella his elde≈øt daughter or to any other the prouinces of the Lowcountries with the counte≈ø≈øe of Burgondy and Charlois, that all the ≈øaid Prouinces and counties do vnder≈øtande to b√©e comprehended in this pre≈øent treatie as they were in that of anno. 1559. together with the ≈øaide Princes or he to whome in fauour the ≈øaid king Catholique ≈øhall di≈øpo≈øe the ≈øame without being n√©edefull that to this effect there ≈øhould be made a new treatie.

8 And the ≈øaid ≈øubiects and ≈øeruants of both ≈øides ≈øhall returne vnto their ≈øaid vnmo ‚Ä¢ eable goods & rents afore≈øaid notwith≈øtanding at gifts con ‚Ä¢ embs, declarations, confi≈øcations, & commi≈ø≈øons ≈øentences reneued by continuance and in ab≈øence of the parties, and tho≈øe not heard by of the ≈øaid ‚Ä¢ ares, how≈øoeuer it be, which ≈øentences & all iudgements giuen as well in ciuill as criminall matters ≈øhal remaine voyde and of no worth as if they had not bene pronounced, thereof wholy encrea≈øing the ≈øaide ≈øubiects, cea≈øing all hindrances and contradictions vnto the rightes which they had at the time of the opening of the ≈øaide warre without that any one may be charged for charges publike or entermi≈øes which he had how beit for the victuals, maintainment of money, or otherwi≈øe during the time & occa≈øion of the ≈øaid warres, whereof they ≈øhould haue made account vnto ≈øuch as then had power to di≈øpo≈øe thereof, ≈øo far foorth that the ≈øaid ≈øubiects and ≈øeruants be not founde guiltie of any other crimes, then to haue ≈øerued in contrary party, and not neuerthele≈ø≈øe, retire them≈øelues into the countries and Lord≈øhips of the ≈øaid kings without they haue fir≈øt thereof obtayned permi≈ø≈øion, and letters patents ≈øealed with the great ≈øeale of their Maie≈øtie the which they ≈øhalbe bound to verifie
